item.title: Coronavirus: Schools and workplaces could see 'local lockdowns'
item.description: Restrictions could be introduced if there is a local flare-up of coronavirus, a minister says.

item.title: Coronavirus: Boris Johnson to face senior MPs amid Cummings row
item.description: The PM will appear before the Liaison Committee as critics call for his chief adviser to resign.

item.title: Twitter tags Trump tweet with fact-checking warning
item.description: It is the first time the social media giant has said one of Donald Trump's tweets could be misleading.

item.title: Minnesota violence: Clashes over death of black man in police custody
item.description: Tear gas is fired at protesters angry at the death of a man pinned down by a policeman in Minnesota.

item.title: Hairdressers say they want to open before 4 July
item.description: Salons are asking the government to let them open before July to cut hair.

item.title: UK furlough scheme now covers 8.4 million workers
item.description: The scheme to pay wages of workers on leave because of coronavirus has now cost Â£15bn.

item.title: Premier League clubs agree to contact training
item.description: Premier League clubs agree to resume contact training in the next phase of Project Restart.

item.title: Louise Smith: Man arrested on suspicion of murdering teenager
item.description: The body of 16-year-old Louise Smith was found in woodland in Havant on Thursday.

item.title: Claire Foy and Matt Smith to perform live in empty Old Vic theatre
item.description: The socially-distanced play, featuring The Crown actors, will be streamed live from the Old Vic.

item.title: No decision on all primary years back to school
item.description: Schools minister challenged by MPs over whether all primary years in England will go back next month.

item.title: SpaceX launch: What is SpaceX and why is it working with Nasa?
item.description: Ahead of the launch of the Crew Dragon mission, the BBC explains what SpaceX does exactly

item.title: Walkers found after 19 days in the New Zealand wilderness
item.description: The 23-year-olds were winched from a clearing after a helicopter spotted smoke from their fire.

item.title: Coronavirus: Why barber shops matter to the community
item.description: Barber shops are a central part of a community but how has lockdown changed this?

item.title: Letter from Dunkirk soldier arrives 80 years later
item.description: Pte Harry Cole wrote the letter to his mother just before he was killed but it never made it back.

item.title: Coronavirus: One week in one hospital
item.description: The BBC has been given unprecedented access to a hospital in the heart of London, for one week.

item.title: Denmark embraces live music drive-ins
item.description: Mads Langer performs a drive-in concert for music fans in Copenhagen while social distancing.

item.title: Australia's megafauna roamed the tropics with first humans but then disappeared
item.description: New evidence shows climate change may have wiped out Australia's giant beasts.

item.title: Thirsk woman, 99, to stand 100 times for son's hospice
item.description: As she turns 100, Joyce Richardson, of Thirsk, is raising funds for a hospice that cared for her son.

item.title: Maximus Meadows: Memorial cattery for rescue cat internet star
item.description: Stray cat Maximus touched many hearts when he was rescued from the streets of Sandwell in November.

item.title: Coronavirus: Nurse and doctor wed in hospital where they work
item.description: Jann Tipping and Annalan Navaratnam were given special permission for the ceremony in London.

item.title: Coronavirus: Jamaican bobsleigh team in Peterborough Mini push
item.description: Two team members push a Mini around Peterborough as they cannot use their training facilities.

item.title: Coronavirus: How childminders are caring for children in their own home
item.description: 'Lots of soap' is crucial, say childminders who have stayed open for key workers' children.

item.title: Coronavirus: The human cost of virus misinformation
item.description: A BBC team tracking coronavirus misinformation has found links to assaults, arson and deaths - and the potential for even greater indirect harm.

item.title: Coronavirus: Parents of disabled children 'cut off and ignored'
item.description: Lockdown has left many families with disabled children feeling isolated and without support.

item.title: Soul Boy: The teen who found a home on the dancefloor
item.description: Anthony Flavin spent most of his life in care - a turning point was finding soul on the dancefloor.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'I made a ventilator from a coffee machine'
item.description: Businessman Ross Hunter has reached the finals of a global challenge to create a low-cost ventilator.

item.title: Coronavirus: Why Merkel may help fund Europe's recovery plan
item.description: Germanyâs leader has agreed to shoulder some of the burden, but four "frugal" EU states are unhappy.

item.title: Coronavirus: China's plan to test everyone in Wuhan
item.description: Officials said they planned to test all of Wuhan's residents over 10 days, so how have they done?

item.title: Mumbai: How Covid-19 has ravaged India's richest city
item.description: With nearly 30,000 cases, Mumbai accounts for more than a fifth of India's coronavirus infections.

item.title: Ramsdale's positive coronavirus test shook Bournemouth - Howe
item.description: Bournemouth goalkeeper Aaron Ramsdale's positive coronavirus test has changed the mindset of staff at the club, according to manager Eddie Howe.

item.title: End of home advantage? What Premier League can learn from Bundesliga empty stadiums
item.description: Having watched the Bundesliga restart in Germany, here are four things we have noticed that could affect Premier League games behind closed doors.

item.title: Fight Talk: Tyson Fury, Mike Tyson, Dereck Chisora, Floyd Mayweather and Tommy Fury
item.description: Tyson Fury is lined up by Mike Tyson, Floyd Mayweather is in the ring and some British fighters are angry with one particular American.

item.title: Netball Superleague: 2020 season terminated with immediate effect
item.description: The 2020 Netball Superleague season is terminated with immediate effect because of the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: MOTD podcast - Shearer and Wright discuss best Premier League games
item.description: Our Match of the Day pundits discuss and debate the best Premier League games of all time.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will shops open and what will the rules be?
item.description: Non-essential shops can reopen in England next month, but will I be able to buy a book or have a haircut?

item.title: Dominic Cummings: Did he break lockdown rules?
item.description: The UK PM's most senior adviser has responded to accusations that he broke lockdown rules - what did he say?

item.title: Lockdown update: All you need to know about new measures
item.description: How will social and work life be different after the easing of some restrictions in England?

item.title: How to keep safe while shopping in a coronavirus pandemic
item.description: From one way systems to not touching everything on the shelves - shopping will look very different.

item.title: Coronavirus UK map: How many confirmed cases are there in your area?
item.description: Key graphics explaining how coronavirus has spread in the UK and the government's response.

item.title: Coronavirus: Can it affect eyesight?
item.description: The prime minister's chief adviser says his vision was affected by coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus: What tests are being done in the UK?
item.description: What are the tests for coronavirus, who are they for and how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus pandemic: Tracking the global outbreak
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the respiratory virus has spread around the world and how it is being dealt with.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are social distancing and self-isolation rules?
item.description: Changes have been announced to guidelines in England on exercise and social distancing.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules on caring for children during lockdown?
item.description: A look at the guidance as Downing Street backs Dominic Cummings over his 260-mile lockdown trip.

item.title: Dominic Cummings row: The families who stayed away in lockdown
item.description: Members of the public have expressed anger after the PM's chief adviser travelled to Durham in lockdown.

item.title: Dominic Cummings: Full statement on lockdown row
item.description: The PM's chief adviser told a press conference he wanted to "clear up confusion" amid calls for him to resign.

item.title: Could you have to pay your bank to save money?
item.description: As countries take extreme measures keep the economy afloat, could we see negative interest rates?

item.title: Coronavirus: How does contact tracing work and is my data safe?
item.description: Millions in the UK will soon be asked to monitor who they have been near to combat coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus: How safe are takeaways and supermarket deliveries?
item.description: If coronavirus can be transferred on to surfaces, what are the risks of buying food?

item.title: What's the risk on public transport?
item.description: Bus and train operators are reducing services and increasing cleaning.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the UK travel quarantine rules?
item.description: What do you need to know if you're planning to fly during the Covid-19 pandemic?

item.title: Coronavirus: Can children catch and pass on coronavirus?
item.description: BBC's Health Correspondent Laura Foster explains what we know currently about how children are affected by the virus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Where do governments borrow money?
item.description: How does it work when a government wants to borrow money, and when does it have to pay it back?

item.title: Amazon under threat: Fires, loggers and now virus
item.description: How the loss of the Amazon goes beyond deforestation - and what the nine countries that share this natural resource are doing to protect it.
